questions.text: An 82-year-old man with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by his daughter because of extensive bruising on his arms. He lives in an assisted living facility. Physical examination shows large ecchymoses across both forearms and upper arms in varying stages of healing. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.7 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 78 μm3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm3. Coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bruises?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bruising due to platelet aggregation inhibition can be seen in patients on antiplatelet agents, and most commonly occurs in women > 60 years old who have recently started antiplatelet therapy (duration < 1 month). This patient with Alzheimer disease has a normal platelet count and coagulation studies, bruises in different stages of healing (localized to the upper extremity), and no history of antiplatelet use, all of which should raise concern for a different etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravascular coagulation with fibrinolysis is consistent with a consumptive coagulopathy, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). This patient with bruises localized to the upper extremities, normal platelet count and coagulation studies, and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., due to sepsis or malignancy) is unlikely to have DIC.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased activity of epidermal melanocytes is seen in solar lentigo. Solar lentigines are commonly found on sun-exposed areas including the back of the hands, forehead, and scalp, but not the upper arms. The affected skin shows solitary or multiple dark, sharply demarcated, pigmented macules due to melanin, rather than purple/reddish poorly demarcated lesions due to hemoglobin breakdown.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's bruises on the upper extremity are most likely caused by nonaccidental trauma due to older adult abuse. Older adults, especially those with dementia, are at increased risk for abuse. Older adult abuse is most commonly perpetrated by caregivers (e.g., spouse, nursing home staff) and can be physical, psychological, or financial, or take the form of neglect. Physicians are legally and ethically obligated to report suspected abuse. When a physician suspects abuse, they should privately speak with the affected patient, ask for further information, and offer assistance.

Finally, this patient's decreased MCV and hemoglobin are consistent with microcytic anemia (e.g., due to insufficient iron intake) but do not indicate an increased bleeding risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency causes large ecchymoses, which are seen here, and deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis, hematomas). However, vitamin K deficiency is unlikely in this patient with normal coagulation studies.
questions.hint: This patient's history of dementia and residing in an assisted living facility are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 6 years ago. Three years ago, when he was no longer able to perform daily tasks and take care of himself, the patient moved in with his daughter, who is his surrogate decision-maker. Over the past year, he has been treated twice for food poisoning. He takes no medications. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 56 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. He appears tired and is oriented only to person. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry skin and mucous membranes; capillary refill time is 2 seconds. There is a tender, nonblanching, erythematous area over the patient's sacrum with superficial skin loss. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation and increased bowel sounds. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Neurologic examination shows ankle clonus and an ataxic gait. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 9/30. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 116 μm3, and leukocyte count is 13,800/mm3 (14% eosinophils). Microscopic evaluation of the stool shows multiple eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum. The patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment and further evaluation. The daughter asks if the patient could be treated at home. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Evaluate the patient's eligibility for home hospice care
Provide a prescription for necessary medications and discharge the patient
Obtain the patient's approval for discharge
Reach out to a health care assistance program

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is malnourished, has advanced Alzheimer dementia, and is almost completely dependent in all activities of daily living. The onset and progression of feeding difficulties is a hallmark of advanced dementia, which has a prognosis similar to other end-of-life conditions such as metastatic cancer and stage IV heart failure (i.e., life expectancy < 6 months); therefore, this patient may be eligible for home hospice care. However, his history of food poisoning, dehydration, and unexplained pressure ulcer make another step in management more appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Physicians should consider requests made by surrogate decision-makers if the patient lacks decision-making capacity, which is the case here. However, this patient's unexplained malnutrition and dehydration require further investigation before he is discharged.

C) CORRECT:

Older adult abuse, including older adult neglect, is frequently perpetrated by someone with power over and responsibility for the patient (e.g., a caregiver or relative, as seen here). In this case, the patient presents with signs of malnourishment, dehydration, and an unexplained pressure ulcer, all of which should raise suspicion for older adult neglect. In the US, physicians are legally and ethically obligated to report suspected older adult abuse to Adult Protective Services if the patient lives at home or with a relative or to the Long-Term Care Ombudsman programs if the abuse occurred in an institution (e.g., assisted living facility). Apart from investigating complaints, these agencies protect older adults by providing them with social, medical, and legal aid.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's Mini-Mental State Examination score suggests he has advanced dementia (i.e., any score below 13/30), which means he most likely lacks decision-making capacity. Therefore, he cannot consent to his own discharge.

E) INCORRECT:

Health care assistance programs, which include Medicare and county-specific programs, are financial aid programs designed to improve health care access among low-income individuals. The current state of this patient, who lacks decision-making capacity and is dependent on his daughter for health care, is not the result of a lack of financial resources but neglect; a different step is required in the case of older adult neglect.
questions.hint: This patient, who has severe cognitive impairment, has a fish tapeworm infection, which most likely has led to his megaloblastic anemia. He is also dehydrated, malnourished, and has a pressure ulcer, which cannot be explained by his medical history.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter for evaluation after a fall. The daughter states her mother fell down 5 steps at home 2 days ago and has been increasingly confused since. Medical history includes hypertension and early dementia. On examination, she has a 6-cm bruise on her left upper arm, smaller bruises on her posterior neck, and appears dehydrated. Vital signs are BP, 168/94; P, 90; R, 15. Her daughter says she has not taken her antihypertensive medication in several days. When asked privately about the fall, the patient becomes withdrawn and states she does not remember much. Laboratory studies show sodium 148 mEq/L, BUN 45 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Restart antihypertensive medication and discharge home
Obtain informed consent from patient before taking further action
Discuss home care arrangements with the daughter
Report suspected elder abuse to Adult Protective Services
Perform cognitive screening to assess dementia progression

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restarting medication and discharging home would be inappropriate given the multiple red flags for older adult abuse. The patient's safety must be ensured through proper reporting channels before discharge is considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining informed consent is not required before reporting suspected older adult abuse. Physicians have a legal obligation to report suspected abuse in most states even if reporting goes against the patient's wishes, as patient safety takes precedence over autonomy in these situations.

C) INCORRECT:

Discussing care arrangements with the daughter is inappropriate as she is the suspected perpetrator of older adult abuse. This could compromise patient safety and interfere with proper investigation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The patient presents with multiple red flags for older adult abuse including delay in seeking care, unexplained soft tissue injuries in characteristic locations, dehydration, medication nonadherence, and withdrawn behavior when questioned privately. Emergency physicians have a legal obligation to report suspected older adult abuse to Adult Protective Services in most states.

E) INCORRECT:

Although cognitive screening is recommended in older adult abuse evaluation, the immediate priority is recognizing and reporting the suspected older adult abuse. Cognitive assessment can be performed after patient safety is ensured.
